title: How the slam dunk became this director's metaphor for the Asian American experience
description: When is a dunk more than a dunk? When it's wrapped up in proving yourself to your entire high school.

title: A $3.5 billion accounting error puts the South Carolina comptroller's job on the line
description: State lawmakers angry over the accounting blunder by Comptroller General Richard Eckstrom began efforts to oust him, a day after demanding he quit or be fired. He has signaled he won't resign.

title: Denver donates 35 bison to Native American tribes
description: The transfers marked another example of Indigenous people reclaiming stewardship over the land and animals that their ancestors managed for thousands of years.

title: Activists spread misleading information to fight solar
description: Citizens for Responsible Solar is part of a growing backlash against renewable energy in rural communities across the United States.

title: California storms are taking a toll on farmworkers like those in the town of Pajaro
description: In the area, berry fields have become small lakes, leaving workers without jobs, food and, in some cases, housing.

title: Child care demand outpaces supply. In rural U.S., there may be no supply
description: For many families, its extremely difficult to find child care — especially in rural areas where the need far outweighs any available options.

title: Yellen tries to reassure Americans that bank collapse fallout will be contained
description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says bank depositors can feel confident their money is safe.  Yellen promised a thorough review of what went wrong at two regional banks that failed in the past week.

title: Markey calls Biden's decision to back the Willow Project 'an environmental injustice'
description: The Biden administration approved a major oil extraction project in Alaska, a decision that has divided Democrats. NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Sen. Ed Markey, who opposes the project.

title: First Republic Bank becomes the latest bank to be rescued, this time by its rivals
description: The lenders including J.P.Morgan and Wells Fargo would deposit $30 billion into the beleaguered midsized lender as part of the rescue.

title: Lawmakers are split on how to respond to the recent bank failures
description: Days after the failure of two regional banks shook the financial industry, lawmakers say they want answers but disagree on what role Congress should play right now.

title: 10 Virginia deputies face murder charges in a Black man's death at a mental hospital
description: Irvo Otieno was transferred from jail to a state mental health facility on March 6. Prosecutors say he was handcuffed during the intake process and "smothered" by deputies for some 12 minutes.

title: Drag queen (and ordained minister) Bella DuBalle won't be silenced by new Tenn. law
description: DuBalle says the legislators behind a new law criminalizing public drag shows don't understand the art: "They think that every drag performer is doing something hypersexual or obscene."

title: Runaway goats in San Francisco were probably ... freaked out
description: The video of goats dashing through the streets of San Francisco drew thousands of views on Twitter and was the subject of much joking. We asked a goat specialist to weigh in.

title: Congress steps closer to formally repealing the resolutions authorizing the Iraq wars
description: If the Senate approves a procedural vote Thursday to repeal authorization of the use of force in Iraq, a final vote in the chamber could come near the 20th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq.

title: North Dakota Supreme Court ruling keeps the state's abortion ban on hold for now
description: The state's high court ruled Thursday that a North Dakota abortion ban will remain blocked while a lawsuit over its constitutionality proceeds.

title: The U.K. is the latest to ban TikTok on government phones because of security concerns
description: British authorities said they are banning the Chinese-owned video-sharing app TikTok from government mobile phones following similar moves by the U.S. and European Union.

title: Poland will send fighter jets to Ukraine, the first NATO country to do so
description: Ukraine has long sought fighter jets, though these are old Soviet-made MiG-29s and not the more advanced Western warplanes that Kyiv covets.

title: Mets' Edwin Díaz hurts his knee during a World Baseball Classic celebration
description: New York Mets star closer Edwin Díaz injured his right knee celebrating a win that advanced Puerto Rico in the World Baseball Classic and eliminated the Dominican Republic.

title: A train carrying corn syrup derails in Arizona
description: About eight train cars went off the tracks Wednesday evening in Mohave County, Ariz., near the California border. The incident follows a recent string of high-profile train derailments.

title: French lawmakers vote on Macron's controversial plan to raise the retirement age
description: The bill would raise the retirement age from 62 to 64 and heads toward a climax Thursday, either through a vote or a special presidential action, as protests and strikes roil the country.

title: Credit Suisse shares soar after the bank secures a $54 billion lifeline
description: Shares of the Swiss banking giant rallied significantly Thursday after Switzerland's central bank agreed to lend it $54 billion.

title: The U.S. military releases footage of Black Sea drone crash with Russian jet
description: The 42-second video comes two days after the Pentagon accused a Russian aircraft of colliding with an uncrewed MQ-9 Reaper drone. The Kremlin has denied that it intentionally downed the vehicle.

title: The U.S. is sending an ambassador to India after leaving the job vacant for 26 months
description: It was the longest diplomatic gap in the history of U.S.- Indian relations, at a time when the two countries say they're closer than ever before

title: 'Heart Sutra' is a satire that skewers religious institutions without mocking faith
description: Chinese novelist Yan Lianke treats the deities of China's major religions as quiet, omnipresent participants in the novel's events, which range from slapstick comedy to shocking violence.

title: Sickle cell patient's success with gene editing raises hopes and questions
description: A Mississippi woman's life has been transformed by a treatment for sickle cell disease with the gene-editing technique CRISPR. All her symptoms from a disease once thought incurable have disappeared.

title: The truth is there's little the government can do about lies on cable
description: Tucker Carlson trying to rewrite history on the Jan. 6 riots is exposing the government's limited ability to regulate distortions on cable news.

title: Bobby Caldwell, singer of 'What You Won't Do for Love,' dies at 71
description: Bobby Caldwell's smooth soul jam "What You Won't Do for Love" went to No. 9 on the Billboard Hot 100. It became a long-term standard and career-defining hit for Caldwell, who also wrote the song.

title: Maternal deaths in the U.S. spiked in 2021, CDC reports
description: After years of high rates, the country hit a new high during the pandemic, far exceeding rates in other developed nations. Black women are at especially high risk.

title: Jiang Yanyong, the doctor who exposed the size of the 2003 SARS outbreak, dies at 91
description: Jiang Yanyong was a Chinese military doctor who revealed the full extent of the 2003 SARS outbreak and was later placed under house arrest for his political outspokenness.
